course.subject: MATH
course.name: Advanced Real Analysis I
course.description: Basic topology, continuous function spaces, abstract measure and integration theory, Lp spaces, convexity and inequalities, Hilbert spaces, Banach spaces, Complex measure.

reviews.author: amiajoketouyes
reviews.comment_content: Cover abstract measure space; integral theory; area and coarea formula; elliptic pde
reviews.comment_teaching: The note is pretty clear and the professor's teaching is quite good
reviews.comment_grading:
easy to get full mark in exam; need to take oral exam to get A+ but very easy;

Final exam is open book so we dont have to memorize anything.
reviews.comment_workload:
There is homework but it does not count to the grade.
I spend 3 day revising the final and I skipped a lot of lecture but managed to get full mark in final exam

reviews.author: Rainforest
reviews.title: Pretty good grade with no workload
reviews.comment_content:
Abstract measure theory, from the construction of measure to Lebegue integration theory, Fubini theorem Lp spaces and lebesgue differentiation theorem, with some minor topics.
There are something that we all know happened in Nov. So the class only finished half of the plan.
Textbook: Officially Evans' measure theory and fine properties of functions, but actually he did not follow any textbook. I use Folland, chapter 1-9.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Li Dong's teaching is extremely good. He proved everything, every theorem and every lemma, on the whiteboard. He gave many motivations and deep thoughts behind the result. He really taught us how to do analysis instead of just memorizing theorems.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolutely good. No homework.
Originally there is a final presentation, but since Nov. stuff, he asked us to learn Fourier transf. and distribution theory at home and do a problem as final. He also asked us to hand in lecture notes that we took down in class.
I didnt know how to solve that problem so only submitted the notes. and got an A!!
OMG! He's so generous.
reviews.comment_workload: Zero workload. No homework. Just taking notes down in class will be suffice.

reviews.author: terrykhtong
reviews.comment_content:
Chapter 1 General Measure Theory
Chapter 2 Hausdorff Measures
Chapter 3 Area and Coarea Formulas
(Measure theory and fine properties of functions, by L.C. Evans and R.F. Gariepy)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Basically following the flow of the textbook, but in a faster pace. Assuming some familiarity of analysis and measure theory in $\mathbb{R}$.
If you are able to read the textbook yourself, you don't need to come to the lectures, but the professor won't recognize you in the final exam. Yet if you are interested in Real analysis or related topics such as PDE, he would give his insights to the topics in class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework: 50%.
Final Exam: 50%.

Very good grade. Got A+ despite that I missed two of the questions in final exam out of five questions.
Did not give the homeworks and exams back.
reviews.comment_workload:
Still considering giving a C or D for workload. There are three HWs. If you are a perfectionist, you would find it frustrating that in HW1 and 2, there is a question that requires you to either read a whole chapter of other reference book or an original research paper. You definitely need a month to do that particular part, which I am not interested since my interest is not in real analysis. However, if you choose to neglect this question, you can find the solution of other questions online, and the professor encourage us to do so. In either case you need to type the homework in Latex, which I was not that familiar with.

The final exam only covers Chapter 1 and 2, despite that he taught up to Chapter 3.

Overall the workload is B for some of us, D for some others, and so I would give an average C.
